commits.message: add external access code action operation for renaming after refactor
Merge branch 'main' of https://github.com/dotnet/roslyn into dev/pranas/renamecodeactionoperation
Merge branch 'main' of https://github.com/dotnet/roslyn into dev/pranas/renamecodeactionoperation

Merge pull request #70531 from PranavSenthilnathan/dev/pranas/renamecodeactionoperation

Add external access code action operation for renaming after code actions

pull_request.title: Add external access code action operation for renaming after code actions
pull_request.body:
Roslyn will invoke navigation or inline renaming after code actions if a resultant document from the code action has a navigation token or rename token in the syntax tree. For languages that don't use syntax trees (TypeScript), Roslyn only supports navigation by position. This PR adds inline renaming by position for these languages.

The new external access operation is similar to the [`DocumentNavigationOperation`](https://github.com/dotnet/roslyn/blob/5faf7b5a3bb6a02ac22f80fa00fb9c8ba2ac153e/src/Features/Core/Portable/Common/DocumentNavigationOperation.cs) which is special cased to navigate to a position after a code action.

labels.description: The pull request was submitted by a contributor who is not a Microsoft employee.

issue.title: Add support for more StringSyntaxAttribute syntaxes

milestone.title: Backlog

issue.body:
.NET 7 adds the new [StringSyntax(...)] attribute, which Roslyn is now already recognizing in support of the StringSyntaxAttribute.DateTimeFormat/Regex/Json values.  https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/pull/67621 is rounding out the named syntaxes on the attribute with an additional set, while also attributing all relevant parameters across the core libraries with these:

- [ ] "CompositeFormat" - a composite format string (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/base-types/composite-formatting#composite-format-string), like the one passed to string.Format / StringBuilder.AppendFormat.  It'd be great if syntax coloring could be applied to these, as is done for interpolated strings, and ideally syntax validation for composite format strings with invalid syntax (the latter could also be done as an analyzer).
- [ ] "DateOnlyFormat" / "TimeOnlyFormat" - same as "DateTimeFormat", but with only the date-related and time-related specifiers, relatively.  It'd be great if similar IntelliSense could be provided for these as is provided for "DateTimeFormat", just with only the relevant items filtered.
- [ ] "EnumFormat" - a specifier used for how an enum is formatted (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/base-types/enumeration-format-strings).  IntelliSense could do something similar to that for "DateTimeFormat", and warn when an unsupported option is used.
- [ ] "GuidFormat" - a specifier used for how a Guid is formatted or parsed (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.guid.system-iformattable-tostring?msclkid=b56bc8efb52c11ecbb60280f9226ae5d&view=netstandard-1.6#parameters).   IntelliSense could do something similar to that for "DateTimeFormat", and warn when an unsupported option is used.
- [ ] "NumericFormat" - a specifier used for how one of the many numerical types is formatted (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/base-types/standard-numeric-format-strings?msclkid=027a8ed2b52d11ecad542115310f6ce9). IntelliSense could do something similar to that for "DateTimeFormat".
- [ ] "TimeSpanFormat" - a specifier used for how to format TimeSpan instances (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/base-types/standard-timespan-format-strings)
- [ ] "Uri" - URLs. Syntax coloring and validation could be employed.
- [ ] "Xml" - XML. Syntax coloring and validation could be employed.

cc: @CyrusNajmabadi

comment.body:
Hi, I'm working on a free Visual Studio extension that adds support for GraphQL syntax. The extension is called [GraphQLTools](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=codearchitects-research.GraphQLTools) and it is currently in preview. The source code is available [here](https://github.com/codearchitects/GraphQLTools); I hope that it could be of help to people interested in extending the feature to more languages.
Writing a Visual Studio extension is quite challenging because the documentation is not that exhaustive and we would love to be able to write plugins for the StringSyntaxAttribute feature in a more standardized way.

pull_request.title: Add restore support to the language server
pull_request.body:
First part of https://github.com/dotnet/vscode-csharp/issues/5725

Adds support on the server side for
1.  A handler to retrieve the set of possible projects to restore.  This is used to show a project picker for the project to restore on the client side.
2.  A handler to restore a specified project (or all projects).  This is used once a project is picked from 1), or for the restore all command on the client side.

Followups
1.  Fixing file watching to include project.assets.json (ProjectAssetsFile)
2.  Integration tests on the client
3.  Automatic nuget restore detection

Client side PR - https://github.com/dotnet/vscode-csharp/pull/6603

![restore_projects](https://github.com/dotnet/roslyn/assets/5749229/8e5f728b-494c-4eee-978d-58b882474ded)

+﻿// Licensed to the .NET Foundation under one or more agreements.
+// The .NET Foundation licenses this file to you under the MIT license.
+// See the LICENSE file in the project root for more information.
+
+using System.Collections.Immutable;
+using System.Composition;
+using Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.Host.Mef;
+using Roslyn.Utilities;
+
+namespace Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.LanguageServer.Handler;
+
+/// <summary>
+/// Given an input project (or none), runs restore on the project and streams the output
+/// back to the client to display.
+/// </summary>
+[ExportCSharpVisualBasicStatelessLspService(typeof(RestoreHandler)), Shared]
+[Method(MethodName)]
+[method: ImportingConstructor]
+[method: Obsolete(MefConstruction.ImportingConstructorMessage, error: true)]
+internal class RestoreHandler(DotnetCliHelper dotnetCliHelper) : ILspServiceRequestHandler<RestoreParams, RestorePartialResult[]>
comment.body:

```suggestion
internal sealed class RestoreHandler(DotnetCliHelper dotnetCliHelper)
    : ILspServiceRequestHandler<RestoreParams, RestorePartialResult[]>
```

pull_request.title: Update the approach we use to layer classifications
pull_request.body:
Idea though of by @sharwell .

This replaces the current approach we have with classification where we have 3 independent taggers (one for syntax, one for semantics, and one for embedded classification), and replaces it with 1 tagger that internally has 3 tagging components it defers to and aggregates.

THe problem with the former approach is that it led to undesirable scenarios where users might do things like comment out a line of code and then see semantic classifications still show up.  This was because each classifier was independent, and so the same section of code might classified as a comment by the syntactic classifier, but a symbol by the semantic one (which hadn't caught up yet).

Prior approaches to try to resolve this worked by attempting to place these classifications on different editor layers, which allowed things like comments to override non-commented code.  While this worked, Sam had a cleaner idea.  Instead of having different taggers that conflicted with each other, we would just have a single tagger that aggregated the results of all three sub-tagging-components.  This aggregating tagger could then add the smarts about having syntactic comments override semantic tags, as well as a nice way of having embedded tags (regex/json/c#-test) always override string tags.

This turned out to be nice and easy to do, and decouples us from teh editor layering system.  It also means we should no longer have to worry about any issues in the future stemming from our classifiers being independent, which may be nice in the future for future classification enhancements we may have.

auto_merge.commit_message: Update the approach we use to layer classifications

pull_request.title: Revert "[main] Update dependencies from dotnet/arcade (#70482)"
pull_request.body:
This reverts commit fa5e62e2acebb0a28dd6dc0b128d8840e8b0ddb6.

The PR we are reverting updated to a nightly build of the dotnet SDK. We prefer to have Roslyn use a public preview of the SDK if at all possible in order to make life easier for our contributors.

pull_request.title: Keep unsplit states when analyzing sequence points and sequences
pull_request.body:
We were hitting an assertion in `MethodToStateMachineRewriter.VisitAssignmentOperator` (line 835) due to an unexpected local for which we didn't assign a proxy. In Release mode, it looks like we generally don't want to pre-allocate proxies (see `ShouldPreallocateNonReusableProxy`), so that explains why we didn't assign a proxy. The question was then whether we really needed to hoist this local. 
The logic that decides which variables to hoist and what proxies to assign is in `IteratorAndAsyncCaptureWalker.Analyze` (in particular `variablesToHoist.AddRange(walker._variablesToHoist)`). I noticed that in Release mode, we don't hoist `e1` in this scenario, so I followed the trail to see why we decided to hoist `e2`.

It turns out that in `VisitCall` we check whether the receiver is assigned (`CheckAssigned`) and if it's not then `CaptureVariable` adds it to `_variablesToHoist`. That's where the problem became apparent: in the body of the `catch` clause, we should consider `e2` assigned.

We did not consider `e2` assigned, because we were losing useful conditional definite assignment information due to calls to `Unsplit()` in `VisitRvalue()` which was used in `VisitSequencePointExpression(...)` and `VisitSequence(...)`.

commits.message: Run analyzer consistency checks on .NET Core (#70517)

issue.title: VBCSCompiler doesn't load changed dll referenced as analyzer reference
issue.body:
**Version Used**: 
8.0.100-preview.4.23260.5

**Steps to Reproduce**:
Create a solution with 2 projects: 

- Project A: a project with a source generator 
- Project B: has analyzer reference to Project A and uses generated code

1. Specify some usage of the generated file in Project B
2. Build using `dotnet build`
3. Make changes in Project A, e.g. change the generated class name
4. Build using `dotnet build` again

**Expected Behavior**:
The generated code in Project B is changed based on the changes in Project A source generators. The same behavior in Visual Studio

**Actual Behavior**:
The generated code in Project B has not changed

**Workaround**:
Shutdown VBCSComiler instance by specifying `dotnet build-server shutdown`

### Root Cause

The current Shadow Copy Assembly loader doesn't check the MVID of the built assembly, so once you build dll and it is loaded to VBCSComiler, it will be in the memory till the end of the process

But why does everything work fine in Visual Studio? There is an AnalyzerConsistencyChecker that checks the Mvid of compiled assemblies and returns an error if the Mvid is different. So once VBCSCompiler returns an error it closes and restarted by Visual Studio.

Unfortunately, this checker is disabled for NetCore: https://github.com/dotnet/roslyn/commit/158ba3aaff230b1b89284406323fcc79fa2d04e2

So at this moment, CLT tools don't allow us to work with local Source Generators properly, without shutting down VBCSComiler before every build.

pull_request.title: Run analyzer consistency checks on .NET Core
pull_request.body:
The job of `AnalyzerConsistencyChecker` is to determine when the compiler server has loaded analyzers in a bad state and force a restart. One of the bad states it detects is when the analyzers on disk change. That is not handled by `AnalyzerAssemblyLoader` because it has an invariant that the file system is unchanged. This was not running for .NET Core so this particular scenario was missed. This change updates `AnalyzerConsistencyChecker` to run on .NET Core too to catch these issues.

closes #70053
